title: How to Avoid Friends While Studying

steps.title: Set up a comfortable, solo study space in your room.
steps.content: Set up a comfortable, solo study space in your room. Alternatively, work in the living room or use the dining room table as a desk. Whichever room you choose, make sure it's free of distractions. [1] X Expert Source Alexander Ruiz, M.Ed. Educational Consultant Expert Interview. 18 June 2020. Turn off the TV, ask your siblings to keep the noise down, and keep background music at a quiet volume. Studying at home ensures that your friends won't walk by and distract you at any moment. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Find a desk that's tucked away and private.
steps.content: Find a desk that's tucked away and private. Since talking (or at least talking loudly) is usually prohibited in the library, it's a good choice when you're looking to avoid your friends. Set up your notebook, laptop, and whatever else you need at a private desk and stay focused. [3] X Research source Visit your school library or go to the public library in your neighborhood for a change of pace. If your friend walks by in the library and asks to sit with you, politely say that you need to study alone.

steps.title: Choose one that your friends don't often frequent.
steps.content: Choose one that your friends don't often frequent. A coffee shop provides a calm, quiet ambiance for focused studying. Get some coffee or tea to stay energized, pick a one-person table, and set up your study materials. [4] X Research source If you're easily distracted, pick a coffee shop that's not super busy. It can be hard to focus in a crowded, fast-paced environment.

steps.title: It's easy to get distracted when you don't have an agenda.
steps.content: It's easy to get distracted when you don't have an agenda. Make a plan for everything you want to accomplish during your study session. Write it down to keep track of what you do as you go. Tell yourself that you can't hang out or text your friends until you finish your study goals for the day. [5] X Research source Check off the tasks you complete as you go! This can build your momentum and make you feel accomplished.

steps.title: Text notifications, phone calls, and emails can make it hard to focus.
steps.content: Text notifications, phone calls, and emails can make it hard to focus. Try putting your phone on "Do Not Disturb" mode so that you don't get any text alerts or phone calls while you study. If your phone doesn't have this setting, turn off notifications and put it on silent. When you're using your computer, try disabling email notifications and logging out of your social media accounts so that you won't be as tempted to check them. [6] X Research source You could also just put your phone somewhere you're not able to reach it. [7] X Expert Source Alexander Ruiz, M.Ed. Educational Consultant Expert Interview. 18 June 2020. If you have a really hard time not checking your phone, schedule breaks throughout your study time to check it. For example, reward yourself with 5 minutes of phone time after completing a reading.

steps.title: This is a way to avoid your friends virtually.
steps.content: This is a way to avoid your friends virtually. Apps like Freedom block social media and other websites of your choice so that you can't check them while you're studying. Schedule the amount of time you would like to block the websites and sync the app so that it also blocks them on your laptop or computer. [8] X Research source If you really struggle with checking social media while you study, these apps are another way to hold yourself accountable.

steps.title: If you can't get work done, kindly excuse yourself to study at home.
steps.content: If you can't get work done, kindly excuse yourself to study at home. If your friends and study buddies are actually analyzing what happened at the spring formal, excuse yourself to study in a quiet, distraction-free environment like the library or your room at home. Be polite and let them know that you can catch up with everyone when you're finished with your work. [9] X Research source Say something like, "I'm having more trouble with these vocab words than I thought. I think I need to go home to study for a bit. See y'all tomorrow!"

steps.title: This can help if you have to study at school and can't escape them.
steps.content: This can help if you have to study at school and can't escape them. That way, you can at least drown out their noise! Listen to some peaceful, calming music to help you focus on your studies. Use noise-canceling headphones for some extra peace and quiet. [10] X Research source If you don't like listening to music while you study, you can still use headphones to tune out the noise. Simply put on your headphones without turning on any music so your friends will know not to bother you.

steps.title: Don't let your friends convince you not to study.
steps.content: Don't let your friends convince you not to study. Be clear and stand up for what you want to do. A true friend will understand if you need some time to study quietly. [11] X Research source Say something like, "I'd love to hang out this weekend, but I've got a big test tomorrow and I really need to study tonight. I hope you understand!"
